Alfalfa Mosaic Virus.causal agent: Alfalfa Mosaic Virus (AMV), an RNA virus of the genre *alfamovirus *, family *bromoviridae *
Alfalfa Mosaic Virus.description: Virus with broad spectrum of hosts, transmitted mainly by aphids. It causes mosaics and deformations on many plants.
Alfalfa Mosaic Virus.symptoms: Yellow mosaics, leafy deformations, rabougreation, punctual necrosis on leaves and fruits.
Alfalfa Mosaic Virus.development: Rapid transmission by aphids. The virus persists in plant tissues and can infect new plants in a few minutes.
Alfalfa Mosaic Virus.active ingredient: No direct antiviral treatment. Verctors control: Pyrethrinoids, Horticultural oils.
Alfalfa Mosaic Virus.treatment: Elimination of infected plants, fight against aphids, use of resistant varieties, distance from sensitive cultures.

Aphids.description: Small insects-sucking insects who feed on sap and transmit many plant viruses.
Aphids.symptoms: Craft leaves, slowed growth, sticky honey, black fumagine, presence of ants.
Aphids.development: Quick reproduction, often asexual. Several generations per season. Frequent migration between plants.
Aphids.active ingredient: Pyrethrinoids, insecticide soap, Neem oil, spinosad
Aphids.treatment: Sunflower spraying, introduction of natural predators (ladybugs), biological or chemical treatments depending on the threshold.

Armyworms.crop: Corn, rice, wheat, lawn, leafy vegetables
Armyworms.causal agent: Nocturnal butterflies of the genre *spodoptera *, in particular *spodoptera frugiperda *(Automn army)
Armyworms.description: Very voracious caterpillars that move en masse, causing rapid and severe defoliations.
Armyworms.symptoms: Holes in the leaves, cut stems, brown areas, presence of many caterpillars.
Armyworms.development: Quick cycle (30–60 days). The larvae cause the majority of damage. Several generations per year.
Armyworms.treatment: Active monitoring, early treatment, residue management, encouragement of natural enemies.

Bacterial Canker.causal agent: * Clavibacter Michiganensis* subsp. * Michiganensis* (cmm), Gram-post bacteria
Bacterial Canker.description: Systemic bacterial disease causing channinaries, wilts and lesions on fruits and stems.
Bacterial Canker.symptoms: Brown spots, chancres on branches, elaboration of gum, unilateral wilting.
Bacterial Canker.development: Propagation by infected seeds, tools, splashes. Favored in wet and fresh weather.
Bacterial Canker.treatment: Pruning in summer, tool disinfection, preventive copper application, elimination of infected plants.

Bacterial Speck.causal agent: Pseudomonas Syringae PV. Tomato, Gram-negative bacteria
Bacterial Speck.description: Bacterial disease mainly affecting tomatoes, causing dark lesions on leaves and fruits.
Bacterial Speck.symptoms: Small black spots on the leaves with yellow halo, superficial lesions on green fruits, sometimes driven or raised.
Bacterial Speck.development: Favored by fresh and humid conditions (18–24 ° C). Spreads by water splashes, contaminated tools or seeds.
Bacterial Speck.treatment: Use certified seeds, avoid sprinkling by sprinkling, apply copper -based treatments before rains, cultural rotation.

Bacterial Tache.description: Bacterial disease causing dark spots on leaves, stems and fruits, often confused with the speck.
Bacterial Tache.symptoms: Wet stains becoming brown/black, sometimes surrounded by a yellow halo. Lesions on sunk and liégous fruits.
Bacterial Tache.development: Develops in warm and humid weather. Propagates by the seeds, splashes and contaminated tools.
Bacterial Tache.treatment: Use healthy seeds, disinfect tools, apply copper -based preventive treatments, 2–3 year old cultural rotation.

Beet Curly Top Virus.causal agent: Beet Curly Top Virus (BCTV), genre *Curtovirus *, family *geminiviridae *
Beet Curly Top Virus.description: Viruses transmitted by the hacking of beet, causing leafy deformations and a growth stop.
Beet Curly Top Virus.symptoms: Leaves wrapped up, thickened, yellowing, secondary excess roots, slowed growth.
Beet Curly Top Virus.development: Transmitted persistently by *TENELLUS circulifer *. The virus remains active in the insect throughout its life.
Beet Curly Top Virus.active ingredient: No antiviral treatment. Vector control: Pyrethrinoids, horticultural oils.
Beet Curly Top Virus.treatment: Use resistant varieties, eliminate host weeds, install anti-insect nets, avoid infested areas.

Beet leafhopper.causal agent: *TENELLUS CIRCULIFER*, CICADELLE Vector of the BCTV
Beet leafhopper.description: Insect-sucker responsible for the transmission of the beet frying virus.
Beet leafhopper.symptoms: Jeurvening, rolled up leaves, slowed growth, symptoms linked to the transmitted virus.
Beet leafhopper.development: Multiple generations per year. Moves with the wind. Eggs laid in plant tissues.
Beet leafhopper.treatment: Monitoring, fighting weeds hosts, anti-insect nets, targeted treatments at the start of infestation.

Beetles and leafhoppers.crop: Various cultures: beet, tomato, bean, luzerne
Beetles and leafhoppers.causal agent: Various beetles (eg*epicauta spp.*) And cicadelles (*Empoasca spp.*,*Circulifer Tenellus*)
Beetles and leafhoppers.description: Group of pest insects causing direct (bites, sucking) and indirect (virus transmission) damage.
Beetles and leafhoppers.symptoms: Perforated, rolled, yellowed, slowed growth, presence of oozing or necrosis.
Beetles and leafhoppers.development: Rapid reproduction, several generations per year. Some vectors transmit persistent viruses.
Beetles and leafhoppers.treatment: Monitoring, elimination of weeds, anti-insect nets, biological or chemical treatments depending on the threshold.

Big Bud.description: A mite responsible for the abnormal swelling of the buds, which can transmit the reversion virus.
Big Bud.symptoms: Rounded and swollen buds in winter, not hatched in the spring, reduction of flowering and yield.
Big Bud.development: Mites enter the buds in summer. They multiply there and prevent their development in the following spring.
Big Bud.active ingredient: No approved treatment. Sulfur and horticultural oils tested experimentally.
Big Bud.treatment: Eliminate and burn swollen buds in winter, tear off the highly infested plants, plant resistant varieties (eg ‘Ben Hope’).

Blossom End Rot.causal agent: Physiological imbalance due to calcium deficiency
Blossom End Rot.description: Non -pathogenic disorder affecting development fruit, caused by poor absorption of calcium.
Blossom End Rot.symptoms: Dark spots and driven at the lower end of the fruit, becoming brown then black, sometimes with secondary mold.
Blossom End Rot.development: Often appears on the first fruits. Favored by irregular watering, an excess of nitrogen or a soil poor in calcium.
Blossom End Rot.active ingredient: Calcium chélates, calcium nitrate, calcium leaf sprays
Blossom End Rot.treatment: Maintain constant humidity, avoid excess nitrogen, enrich the calcium soil, preventive leaf spray.

Anthracnose cashew.description: Fungal disease causing lesions on leaves, flowers and fruits, greatly reducing the yield.
Anthracnose cashew.symptoms: Brown spots with black on leaves, stunted flowers, deformed or rotten fruits, premature fall.
Anthracnose cashew.development: Quickly spreads in warm and humid weather. Spores persist on plant debris.
Anthracnose cashew.treatment: Pruning of infected parts, fungicidal treatments during sensitive period, cultural rotation, ventilation of plantations.

GUMOSIS CHEPARD.description: Gum flow on the trunk or branches, often linked to stress or secondary infections.
GUMOSIS CHEPARD.symptoms: Vertical slits on the trunk, oozing of amber gum, blackening of the bark.
GUMOSIS CHEPARD.development: Favored by injuries, excessive humidity or pest attacks. Can cause a general weakening.
GUMOSIS CHEPARD.treatment: Improve drainage, avoid injury, disinfect tools, remove the infected bark to the healthy fabric.

Healthy cashew.description: Vigorous plant, without symptoms of illness or stress, with good vegetative and reproductive development.
Healthy cashew.symptoms: Dark green foliage, regular growth, normal flowering and fruiting.
Healthy cashew.development: A good health condition is maintained by suitable cultural practices and regular monitoring.
Healthy cashew.treatment: Good irrigation management, balanced fertilization, sanitary size, preventive phytosanitary surveillance.

CHERNE CHEPDARY.description: Insects whose larvae dig galleries in the leaves, reducing photosynthesis.
CHERNE CHEPDARY.symptoms: Silvering silver drag on the leaves, partial drying, premature fall of the leaves.
CHERNE CHEPDARY.development: Quick multiplication in hot season. Adults lay on young leaves.
CHERNE CHEPDARY.treatment: Elimination of affected leaves, targeted insecticide treatments, introduction of natural parasitoids.

Red Rust cashew.description: Disease caused by a reddish algae, affecting the leaves, branches and sometimes fruits.
Red Rust cashew.symptoms: Reddish or orange spots on the leaves, sometimes powder, blackened or deformed branches.
Red Rust cashew.development: Develops in hot and humid conditions. The algae penetrates by stomates or injuries.
Red Rust cashew.treatment: Pruning of affected parts, fungicidal treatments based on copper, improvement in ventilation and drainage.

Cercospora Fache leaf (Frogeye).causal agent: Mushrooms of the genre *Cercle *, notably *Cercle Beticola *, *c. Capsici *, *c. melongenae*
Cercospora Fache leaf (Frogeye).description: Fungal disease causing circular leaf spots with clear centers and dark edges, evoking a frog eye.
Cercospora Fache leaf (Frogeye).symptoms: Small round stains with gray or light brown center and purple to black edge. The lesions can merge, resulting in the fall in the leaves.
Cercospora Fache leaf (Frogeye).development: Favored by hot and humid conditions. Spores spread through wind, rain or tools. The fungus survives in plant debris.
Cercospora Fache leaf (Frogeye).treatment: Cultural rotation, elimination of debris, preventive fungicidal treatments, ground irrigation to avoid splashes.

Choanephora burn (Wet Rot).description: Fungal disease affecting flowers and fruits, causing wet rot and fluffy fungal development.
Choanephora burn (Wet Rot).symptoms: Floral extremity of soft, brown fruits, covered with white then black or purple. Rotten and withered flowers.
Choanephora burn (Wet Rot).development: Develops quickly in hot and humid weather. Spores propagate by insects, water or wind.
Choanephora burn (Wet Rot).active ingredient: No effective fungicide. Prevention by cultural practices.
Choanephora burn (Wet Rot).treatment: Plant spacing, drip irrigation, suppression of infected fruits, cultural rotation, ventilation of plant cover.

Colorado Potato Beetle.description: Very voracious defolitive insect, capable of quickly destroying the foliage of the Solanaceae.
Colorado Potato Beetle.symptoms: Rodged leaves, irregular holes, red larvae with black dots, yellow eggs under the leaves.
Colorado Potato Beetle.development: 2–3 generations per year. Adults winter in the ground and emerge in the spring. The larvae cause the biggest damage.
Colorado Potato Beetle.active ingredient: Spinosad, imidaclopride, azadirachtine, bacillus thuringiensis var. tenebrionis
Colorado Potato Beetle.treatment: Manual collection, cultural rotation, mulch, targeted treatments, introduction of natural predators (bugs, birds).

Corn Earworm Tomato FruitWorm.description: Polyphage caterpillar which attacks fruit, ears and leaves, causing galleries and loss of yield.
Corn Earworm Tomato FruitWorm.symptoms: Holes in fruits (tomatoes), galleries in corn ears, presence of excrement (frass), rotten fruits.
Corn Earworm Tomato FruitWorm.development: 3 generations per year. The larvae enter the fruits shortly after hatching. Complete cycle in 28–35 days.
Corn Earworm Tomato FruitWorm.treatment: Monitoring with pheromone traps, preventive treatment, cultural rotation, introduction of parasitoids (*trichogrammma spp.*).

CUCUMBER Mosaic Geminiviruses.crop: Cucumber, melon, tomato, pepper, lettuce, spinach
CUCUMBER Mosaic Geminiviruses.description: Very widespread viruses affecting more than 1,200 plant species, transmitted by aphids and contaminated tools.
CUCUMBER Mosaic Geminiviruses.symptoms: Light green/yellow mosaic on the leaves, deformation, navism, bumpy or discolored fruits.
CUCUMBER Mosaic Geminiviruses.development: Rapid transmission by more than 75 species of aphids. The virus persists in weeds and seeds.
CUCUMBER Mosaic Geminiviruses.active ingredient: No antiviral. Verctors control: Pyrethrinoids, Horticultural oils.
CUCUMBER Mosaic Geminiviruses.treatment: Elimination of infected plants, fight against aphids, disinfection of tools, use of resistant varieties.

Cutworms.crop: Share vegetables, tomatoes, cabbage, corn, young sowing
Cutworms.description: Nocturnal caterpillars that cut the young stems at the base, causing the fall of the seedlings.
Cutworms.symptoms: Prunges cut with collar, suddenly withering, presence of larvae wrapped in C in the ground.
Cutworms.development: Active at night, several generations per year. The larvae winter in the ground and emerge in the spring.
Cutworms.treatment: Protective necklaces, binage, deletion of debris, soil treatment, manual trapping, cultural rotation.

Damping-Off & Root Rot.crop: Sowing vegetables, flowers, spinach, tomato, lettuce
Damping-Off & Root Rot.description: Fungal disease affecting sowing and young plants, causing the root rot and the cast iron.
Damping-Off & Root Rot.symptoms: Ramollia stems at the base, plants that are busy, brown or rotten roots, growth stopped.
Damping-Off & Root Rot.development: Appears in cold and humid soil. Spores persist in the ground and spread through water or tools.
Damping-Off & Root Rot.treatment: Use a sterile substrate, avoid excess water, sow good density, treat preventively with fungicides or biostimulants.

Early Burn.description: Fungal disease causing concentric spots on the leaves, stems and fruits, reducing yield.
Early Burn.symptoms: Brown with black stains with concentric circles, yellowing, falling leaves, lesions on stems and fruits.
Early Burn.development: Favored by humidity and moderate temperatures. Spreads by splashes and infected debris.
Early Burn.treatment: Cultural rotation, elimination of debris, preventive fungicidal treatments, spacing of ventilation plants.

False Chinch Bug.description: Small sap sucking insect that moves en masse, causing willing and water stress.
False Chinch Bug.symptoms: Wanned, discolored leaves, slowed growth, presence of small gray-brown insects in groups.
False Chinch Bug.development: Develops on wild crucifers. Massive migration to crops during the drying up of weeds.
False Chinch Bug.treatment: Eliminate host weeds, regular irrigation, physical barriers, treatment in the event of a massive invasion.

Flea Beetles.description: Small co -sealing beetles that puncture the leaves, causing significant damage to young plants.
Flea Beetles.symptoms: Round holes (shotoles) in the leaves, slowed growth, deformed or withered leaves.
Flea Beetles.development: Active from 10 ° C. Adults winter in debris. Several generations per year.
Flea Beetles.treatment: Anti-insect nets, mulching, cultural rotation, targeted treatments at the start of infestation.

Fusarium crownroot rot.description: Fungal -fungal disease causing root and collar rot, withering and death of the plants.
Fusarium crownroot rot.symptoms: Yellowing of low leaves, wilting, brown lesions with collar, rotten roots.
Fusarium crownroot rot.development: Favored by fresh and humid soil. The fungus persists in the soil and plant debris.
Fusarium crownroot rot.active ingredient: No curative treatment. Prevention: grafting, trichoderma spp.
Fusarium crownroot rot.treatment: Use resistant varieties (for), grafting, cultural rotation, improvement in drainage.

Fusarium Wilt.causal agent: * Fusarium oxysporum* f. SP. specific to the host
Fusarium Wilt.description: Vascular fungus blocking the circulation of water, causing the plants of plants and death.
Fusarium Wilt.symptoms: Unilateral wilt, yellowing, vascular browning, progressive death of the plant.
Fusarium Wilt.development: Persists for a long time in the ground. Propagates by contaminated roots, tools or seeds.
Fusarium Wilt.treatment: Use resistant varieties (F1, F2 codes, etc.), long cultural rotation, tool disinfection, grafting.

Gray Facing Leaf.causal agent: * Stempylium SPP.* Or* Cercle Cercle SPP.* According to culture
Gray Facing Leaf.description: Fungal disease causing gray to brown spots on the leaves, reducing photosynthesis.
Gray Facing Leaf.symptoms: Round spots at grayish center, dark edge, sometimes with spores on the surface. Premature fall of the leaves.
Gray Facing Leaf.development: Favored by high humidity and moderate temperatures. Spreads by splashes and wind.
Gray Facing Leaf.treatment: Elimination of infected leaves, preventive fungicidal treatments, plant spacing, ground irrigation.

Hornworms.causal agent: * Manduca quinquemaculata* (Tomato worm),* Manduca sexta* (tobacco worm)
Hornworms.description: Large green caterpillars, very voracious, which consume the leaves, stems and sometimes the fruits of the solanaceae.
Hornworms.symptoms: Devoured leaves, cut stems, visible dark excrement, perforated fruits, presence of large green caterpillars with a posterior horn.
Hornworms.development: Quick cycle in summer. Adults are nocturnal sphinxes. The larvae cause the majority of damage.
Hornworms.treatment: Manual pickup, biological treatment with BT or spinosad, introduction of parasitoids (*COTESIA CONGREGATA*), cultural rotation.

Late burn.description: Devastating disease causing dark lesions on leaves, stems and fruit, causing the rapid rot of the tissues.
Late burn.symptoms: Dark brown spots with fuzzy edges on leaves, blackened stems, brown and soft fruits, smell of rot.
Late burn.development: Spreads quickly in fresh and humid weather. Spores move through wind and water.
Late burn.treatment: Elimination of infected plants, preventive fungicidal treatments, plant spacing, long cultural rotation.

Beetle leaf corn.description: Beetles that gnaw at corn leaves, reducing the photosynthetic surface and weakening the plants.
Beetle leaf corn.symptoms: Linear holes or in strips on the leaves, grilled appearance, slowed growth, presence of brilliant insects.
Beetle leaf corn.development: Adults winter in debris. The larvae feed on the foliar parenchyma. Several generations per year.
Beetle leaf corn.treatment: Monitoring, treatment at the start of infestation, cultural rotation, destruction of culture residues.

Leaf burn corn.causal agent: * Exsertohilum Turcicum* (northern burn),* bipolaris maydis* (southern burn)
Leaf burn corn.description: Fungal diseases causing elongated lesions on the leaves, reducing photosynthesis and yield.
Leaf burn corn.symptoms: Cigarettes (north) or oblong (south), brownish, sometimes bordered with yellow, progression up of the plant.
Leaf burn corn.development: Favored by high humidity and moderate temperatures. Spores persist in residues.
Leaf burn corn.treatment: Cultural rotation, resistant varieties, preventive fungicidal treatments, burial of residues.

Corn Tax leaf.description: Fungal diseases causing brown or black spots on the leaves, reducing photosynthetic capacity.
Corn Tax leaf.symptoms: Oval or elongated spots, sometimes with yellow halo, fusion of lesions in case of severe infection.
Corn Tax leaf.development: Spreads by splashes and wind. Favored by humidity and moderate temperatures.
Corn Tax leaf.treatment: Cultural rotation, tolerant varieties, fungicidal treatments, burial of residues.

Corn Streak Virus.description: Viruses transmitted by the leaflets, causing chlorotic streaks on the leaves and severe navism.
Corn Streak Virus.symptoms: Yellow streaks parallel to the ribs, distorted leaves, slowed growth, absent or poorly trained ears.
Corn Streak Virus.development: Transmitted by *Cicadulina Mbila *. The virus persists in the insect. Early infection = severe losses.
Corn Streak Virus.treatment: Use resistant varieties (e.g. MH26, SC403), eliminate host weeds, early sowing, fighting cicadelles.

Pepper Mottle Pepper.description: Virus transmitted by aphids, causing mosaics, deformations and yield losses on peppers.
Pepper Mottle Pepper.symptoms: Light green/yellow mosaic, deformed leaves, slowed growth, bumpy or striated fruits, falling flowers.
Pepper Mottle Pepper.development: Non -persistent transmission by aphids. More severe infection if it occurs early. Can co-infect with other viruses.
Pepper Mottle Pepper.active ingredient: No antiviral. Verctors control: Pyrethrinoids, Horticultural oils.
Pepper Mottle Pepper.treatment: Use resistant varieties, eliminate infected plants, disinfect tools, control aphids.

Phomopsis burn.description: Mushroom causing burns of shoots, channies and leaf spots, especially on young fabrics.
Phomopsis burn.symptoms: Getting young shoots, brown spots on leaves, cannons on stems, fruit deformation.
Phomopsis burn.development: Infection favored by humidity and injuries. Spores winter in dead fabrics.
Phomopsis burn.treatment: Pruning of affected parts, disinfection of tools, preventive fungicide treatments, avoid injury.

Phytoptora Root, Stem, and Crown Rots.description: Oomycetes causing root, collar and stems, causing withered and death of plants.
Phytoptora Root, Stem, and Crown Rots.symptoms: Getting, yellowing, brunette rot with collar, soft roots, blackened stems.
Phytoptora Root, Stem, and Crown Rots.development: Favored by excess water and poorly drained soil. Spores propagate by water, soil or tools.
Phytoptora Root, Stem, and Crown Rots.treatment: Improve drainage, avoid excess water, preventive treatments, long cultural rotation.

Leaf Theopper potato.description: Insect sap sucking causing foliar burns and sometimes transmitting phytoplasms.
Leaf Theopper potato.symptoms: Marginal yellowing, winding of leaves, slowed growth, burned appearance (hopperburn).
Leaf Theopper potato.development: Multiple generations per year. Frequent migration. More severe damage in hot and dry weather.
Leaf Theopper potato.treatment: Monitoring, anti-insect nets, targeted treatments, elimination of host weeds.

Y tobacacco andch potato.causal agent: *Potato virus y*(pvy) and*tobacco etch virus*(tev), genre*potyvirus*
Y tobacacco andch potato.description: Virus transmitted by aphids, causing mosaics, necrosis and deformations on leaves and tubers.
Y tobacacco andch potato.symptoms: Mosaic, necrosis, streaks on leaves, naism, deformed or necrotic tubers.
Y tobacacco andch potato.development: Rapid transmission by aphids. Early infection = severe losses. Frequent co-infections.
Y tobacacco andch potato.active ingredient: No antiviral. Verctors control: Pyrethrinoids, Horticultural oils.
Y tobacacco andch potato.treatment: Use resistant varieties, eliminate infected plants, disinfect tools, fight aphids.

Powdery Mildew on Vegetables.crop: Zucchini, cucumber, tomato, pea, bean, lettuce
Powdery Mildew on Vegetables.description: Mushrooms causing white felting on the leaves, reducing photosynthesis and yield.
Powdery Mildew on Vegetables.symptoms: White stains powder on leaves, yellowing, drying, premature fall.
Powdery Mildew on Vegetables.development: Develops in hot and dry weather with high ambient humidity. Propagates by the wind.
Powdery Mildew on Vegetables.treatment: Eliminate the affected leaves, preventive treatments, plant spacing, resistant varieties.

Root-knot nematodes.description: Microscopic nematodes causing galls on the roots, reducing the absorption of water and nutrients.
Root-knot nematodes.symptoms: Wales on the roots, wilting, yellowing, slowed growth, reduced yield.
Root-knot nematodes.development: Multiple cycles per year in hot climate. Eggs persist in the ground for several years.
Root-knot nematodes.treatment: Cultural rotation, solarization, resistant varieties, organic amendments, biocontrol.

Thrips.description: Small sucking insects causing discoloration, deformations and transmitting viruses (eg TSWV).
Thrips.symptoms: Sleeping of leaves, black spots (excrement), deformed fruits, slowed growth.
Thrips.development: Multiple generations per year. Develop quickly in a greenhouse or in hot and dry weather.
Thrips.treatment: Blue traps, anti-insect nets, targeted treatments, introduction of predators (eg *Orius spp. *).

Tobacco Mosaic Virus & Tomato Mosaic Vir.causal agent: Tobacco Mosaic Virus (TMV) and Tomato Mosaic Virus (Tomv), genre *Tobamovirus *
Tobacco Mosaic Virus & Tomato Mosaic Vir.description: Very stable viruses transmitted mechanically, causing mosaics, deformations and loss of yield.
Tobacco Mosaic Virus & Tomato Mosaic Vir.symptoms: Light/dark green mosaic, deformed or fern -shaped leaves, slowed growth, necrotic or striated fruits.
Tobacco Mosaic Virus & Tomato Mosaic Vir.development: Seed transmission, tools, hands, tobacco. Very persistent in plant debris (several years).
Tobacco Mosaic Virus & Tomato Mosaic Vir.active ingredient: No antiviral. Disinfection: skim milk, soap, iodized solutions.
Tobacco Mosaic Virus & Tomato Mosaic Vir.treatment: Use healthy seeds, disinfect tools, avoid tobacco, eliminate infected plants, resistant varieties.

Tobamoviruses.causal agent: Genre * Tobamovirus * (Ex. TMV, TOMV, PMMOV, TOBRFV)
Tobamoviruses.description: Very stable family of virus affecting many cultures, transmitted by contact and seeds.
Tobamoviruses.symptoms: Mosaic, deformations, necrosis, striated or bumpy fruits, naism, chlorosis of the ribs.
Tobamoviruses.development: Mechanical transmission. Very persistent on tools, clothes, seeds. No known insect vector.
Tobamoviruses.active ingredient: No antiviral. Disinfection: skim milk, soap, chlorinated solutions.
Tobamoviruses.treatment: Strict hygiene, certified seeds, resistant varieties, elimination of infected plants, cultural rotation.

Russet tomato mite.description: Acvisible mite to the naked eye, causing browning of the stems and leaves, and a general weakening.
Russet tomato mite.symptoms: Craft leaves, bronze or rusty appearance, brown stems, deformed or rough fruits, falling leaves.
Russet tomato mite.development: Develops in hot and dry weather. Infestation often detected late. Spreads from bottom to top.
Russet tomato mite.treatment: Early monitoring, localized treatment, sulfur spray (avoid> 30 ° C), elimination of plants strongly affected.

Tacheted Wilt Virus tomato.description: Viruses transmitted by thrips, causing willing, annular spots and fruit deformations.
Tacheted Wilt Virus tomato.symptoms: Bronzed leaves, withered, yellow or brown annular stains, deformed or necrotic fruits, slowed growth.
Tacheted Wilt Virus tomato.development: Transmitted by Thrips (eg *Frankliniella Westernalis *). Early infection = severe losses. No semen transmission.
Tacheted Wilt Virus tomato.active ingredient: No antiviral. Verctors control: spinosad, insecticide soap.
Tacheted Wilt Virus tomato.treatment: Eliminate infected plants, control thrips, use resistant varieties (TSWV), anti-insect nets, weeding.

Blossom-End Rot Chemical Damage Tospurus.causal agent: Physiological imbalance (calcium deficiency) or chemical damage (excess fertilizer or phytotoxicity)
Blossom-End Rot Chemical Damage Tospurus.description: Non -pathogenic disturbance caused by water or nutritional stress, often confused with viral symptoms.
Blossom-End Rot Chemical Damage Tospurus.symptoms: Brown spots at the end of the fruits (Blossom-End Rot), leaf burns, deformations, localized necrosis.
Blossom-End Rot Chemical Damage Tospurus.development: Favored by irregular watering, excess of nitrogen, inappropriate pH, or excessive application of chemicals.
Blossom-End Rot Chemical Damage Tospurus.treatment: Regular watering, balanced fertilization, leaf calcium spraying, avoid excess chemicals.

Two-tacheted spider mite.description: Very polyphagous devastating mite, causing discoloring, canvases and weakening of plants.
Two-tacheted spider mite.symptoms: Stippling (white points), yellow then brown leaves, fine fabrics, falling leaves, slowed growth.
Two-tacheted spider mite.development: Develops quickly in hot and dry weather. Several generations per year. Infestation often at the base of plants.
Two-tacheted spider mite.active ingredient: Abamectine, spirototetramatis, horticultural oils, insecticide soap
Two-tacheted spider mite.treatment: Targeted spraying, introduction of predators (*phytoseiulus persimilis*), avoid water stress, regular monitoring.

Western striped and stain cucumber beetl.description: Cecurbit pests pests, managers of direct damage and disease vectors such as bacterial wilt.
Western striped and stain cucumber beetl.symptoms: Perforated leaves, healed fruits, slowed growth, wilting. Presence of striped or spotted insects.
Western striped and stain cucumber beetl.development: Adults emerge in the spring, lay at the foot of the plants. The larvae attack roots, adults the leaves and fruits.
Western striped and stain cucumber beetl.treatment: Reflective mulch, nets, yellow traps, targeted treatments at the start of infestation, cultural rotation.

Whiteflies.description: Small winged insects sucks of sap, causing weakening of plants and transmission of viruses.
Whiteflies.symptoms: Yellowed, sticky leaves (honeydew), black fumagine, slowed growth, theft of white insects at the slightest movement.
Whiteflies.development: Multiple generations per year. Develop quickly in a greenhouse or in hot and dry weather.
Whiteflies.treatment: Yellow traps, foliar spraying, introduction of parasitoids (*Encoursia Formosa*), avoid excess of nitrogen.

Yellow Mosaic Potato X.description: Virus causing mosaics, navism and deformations, transmitted by aphids or contaminated equipment.
Yellow Mosaic Potato X.symptoms: Yellow mosaic, blistered or tense leaves, slowed growth, deformed or necrotic tubers.
Yellow Mosaic Potato X.development: Non -persistent transmission by aphids. Frequent co-infections with PVX or TEV worsening symptoms.
Yellow Mosaic Potato X.active ingredient: No antiviral. Verctors control: Pyrethrinoids, Horticultural oils.
Yellow Mosaic Potato X.treatment: Use certified seeds, eliminate infected plants, disinfect tools, control aphids.

Anthracnosis.crop: Bean, tomato, cucumber, mango, papaya, citrus
Anthracnosis.description: Mushroom causing dark spots on leaves, stems and fruits, often with post-harvest rot.
Anthracnosis.symptoms: Brown or black spots, pressed, sometimes with pink masses of spores. Rotting or deformed fruits.
Anthracnosis.development: Spreads by splashes, tools, seeds. Favored by high humidity and heat.
Anthracnosis.treatment: Cultural rotation, healthy seeds, preventive fungicidal treatments, elimination of infected debris.

Apple Apple scab.description: Fungal disease causing black spots on leaves and fruits, reducing commercial quality.
Apple Apple scab.symptoms: Velvet stains brown-olive on leaves, deformed or cracked fruits, premature fall of the leaves.
Apple Apple scab.development: Spores released in the spring from the dead leaves. Infections favored by prolonged humidity.
Apple Apple scab.treatment: Picking up dead leaves, fungicidal treatments with debt, resistant varieties (eg ‘Liberty’).

Black Rot apple.description: Mushroom causing black rot of fruits, channies on branches and leaf stains.
Black Rot apple.symptoms: Brown circular spots on fruits (beef eye), channies on branches, tied leaves in V.
Black Rot apple.development: Winter in chancres and mummified fruits. Spreads by rain and wind in the spring.
Black Rot apple.treatment: Pruning of affected branches, elimination of mummified fruits, preventive fungicidal treatments.

Apple Cedar Apple Rust.description: Heteroic rust requiring apple and juniper. Causes orange spots and deformations.
Apple Cedar Apple Rust.symptoms: Vive orange spots on leaves, protuberances on the underside, deformed or striated fruits.
Apple Cedar Apple Rust.development: Spores released from Wales on juniper in the spring. Pommers' infection during wet period.
Apple Cedar Apple Rust.treatment: East the juniper, fungicidal treatments at the pink stadium, resistant varieties (eg ‘Liberty’).

Healthy apple.description: Vigorous tree, without symptoms of diseases or stress, with good vegetative and reproductive development.
Healthy apple.symptoms: Dark green foliage, regular growth, normal flowering and fruiting, absence of stains or deformations.
Healthy apple.development: Maintaining a good health condition by suitable cultural practices and regular monitoring.
Healthy apple.treatment: Annual size, balanced fertilization, controlled irrigation, preventive phytosanitary surveillance.

Bacterial burn.description: Very contagious bacterial disease affecting the fruit trees with seeds, causing a rapid willing of young shoots.
Bacterial burn.symptoms: Drunk leaves, curled up, burned appearance, bacterial oozing on branches, channies on branches.
Bacterial burn.development: Rapid propagation by rain, insects and tools. Favored in hot and humid weather in the spring.
Bacterial burn.treatment: Severe pruning in dry periods, tool disinfection, preventive copper treatments, surveillance in spring.

Healthy blueberry.description: Vigorous shrub, without symptoms of diseases or stress, with good vegetative and reproductive development.
Healthy blueberry.symptoms: Dark green foliage, regular growth, normal flowering and fruiting, absence of stains or deformations.
Healthy blueberry.development: Maintaining a good health condition by suitable cultural practices and regular monitoring.
Healthy blueberry.treatment: Annual size, balanced fertilization, controlled irrigation, preventive phytosanitary surveillance.

Brown spot.description: Brown spots on leaves or fruits caused by opportunistic mushrooms, often in wet conditions.
Brown spot.symptoms: Circular or irregular spots, dark brown with black, sometimes with yellow halo, lesions on fruits or leaves.
Brown spot.development: Favored by high humidity, injuries, water stress or deficiencies. Can evolve towards the fall of leaves or rot.
Brown spot.treatment: Elimination of affected leaves, preventive fungicide treatments, improvement of ventilation and drainage.

Healthy cherry.description: Vigorous tree, without symptoms of diseases or stress, with good vegetative and reproductive development.
Healthy cherry.symptoms: Brilliant green foliage, abundant flowering, healthy fruits, absence of cannons or spots.
Healthy cherry.development: Maintaining a good health condition by suitable cultural practices and regular monitoring.
Healthy cherry.treatment: Annual size, balanced fertilization, controlled irrigation, preventive phytosanitary surveillance.

Cherry Powdery Mildew.description: Fungal disease causing white felting on young leaves, flowers and fruits, reducing photosynthesis.
Cherry Powdery Mildew.symptoms: White stains powder on leaves, winding, drying, deformed or cracked fruits.
Cherry Powdery Mildew.development: Favored in hot and dry weather with high ambient humidity. Propagates by the wind.
Cherry Powdery Mildew.treatment: Elimination of affected parts, preventive fungicidal treatments, trees spacing, resistant varieties.

Corn (corn) Cercle leaf spot gray leaf.description: Fungal disease causing gray rectangular lesions on the leaves, reducing photosynthesis.
Corn (corn) Cercle leaf spot gray leaf.symptoms: Lying stains, gray to brown, delimited by ribs, possible fusion in case of severe infection.
Corn (corn) Cercle leaf spot gray leaf.development: Favored by high humidity and moderate temperatures. Spreads by splashes and wind.
Corn (corn) Cercle leaf spot gray leaf.treatment: Cultural rotation, resistant varieties, preventive fungicidal treatments, burial of residues.

Corn (Corn) Common Rust.description: Fungal disease causing brown-red pustula on the leaves, reducing the photosynthetic surface.
Corn (Corn) Common Rust.symptoms: Red-brown oval pustules on both sides of the leaves, chlorosis around, drying possible.
Corn (Corn) Common Rust.development: Spreads by the wind from the hot regions. Favored by high humidity and moderate temperatures.
Corn (Corn) Common Rust.treatment: Use resistant hybrids, fungicidal treatments if early appearance, cultural rotation.

Corn (Corn) in good.description: Vigorous plant, without symptoms of diseases or stress, with good vegetative and reproductive development.
Corn (Corn) in good.symptoms: Green leaves, rapid growth, flowering and filling of normal grains, absence of stains or deformations.
Corn (Corn) in good.development: Maintaining a good health condition by suitable cultural practices and regular monitoring.
Corn (Corn) in good.treatment: Balanced fertilization, controlled irrigation, cultural rotation, preventive phytosanitary surveillance.

Corn (Corn) Northern Leaf Burn.description: Fungal disease causing cigar -shaped lesions on the leaves, reducing photosynthesis.
Corn (Corn) Northern Leaf Burn.symptoms: Lying stains, gray-brown, bordered with green or yellow, progression up of the plant.
Corn (Corn) Northern Leaf Burn.development: Favored by prolonged humidity (> 6h) and moderate temperatures (18–27 ° C). Spreads by air spores.
Corn (Corn) Northern Leaf Burn.treatment: Use resistant varieties, cultural rotation, preventive fungicide treatments, burial of residues.

Fall ArmyWorm.crop: Corn, sorghum, rice, cotton, leafy vegetables
Fall ArmyWorm.description: Very mobile and voracious caterpillar, capable of quickly destroying crops by moving en masse.
Fall ArmyWorm.symptoms: Irregular holes in the leaves, galleries in the ears, dark droppings, wilting, presence of caterpillars in groups.
Fall ArmyWorm.development: Quick cycle (30–40 days). The larvae cause 80 % of the damage. Several generations per year. Active migration of adults.
Fall ArmyWorm.active ingredient: Spinosad, Bacillus Thuringiensis (BT), Chlorantraniliprole, Emamectin Benzoate
Fall ArmyWorm.treatment: Monitoring with pheromone traps, early treatment, cultural rotation, introduction of parasitoids (*trichogrammma spp.*), Management of residues.

Black Rot grapes.description: Fungal disease causing lesions on leaves, branches and fruit, causing their rot and mummification.
Black Rot grapes.symptoms: Circular brown spots on leaves, black lesions on branches, rotten fruits and drying out in 'mummies'.
Black Rot grapes.development: The fungus winters in mummified fruits and branches. Spores released in the spring by rain. Quick infection in hot and humid conditions.
Black Rot grapes.treatment: Elimination of mummified fruits, size of the reached branches, fungicidal treatments between deburring and post-flora, tolerant varieties.

Esc (Black Measles) grapes).description: Chronic wood disease causing foliar streaks, drying up, rotting berries and slow deaths of the vines.
Esc (Black Measles) grapes).symptoms: STRIES YELLOW OR RATERS, DRAWING OF THE SHEETS, dark spots on bays, necrotic wood in transverse cut.
Esc (Black Measles) grapes).development: Infection by size wounds. Symptoms visible after several years. Irregular appearance according to the climate.
Esc (Black Measles) grapes).treatment: Double or late size, tool disinfection, elimination of reached vines, application of Trichoderma SPP. on size wounds.

Healthy grapes.description: Vigorous vine foot, without symptoms of diseases or stress, with good vegetative and reproductive development.
Healthy grapes.symptoms: Green foliage, regular growth, normal flowering and fruiting, absence of stains or deformations.
Healthy grapes.development: Maintaining a good health condition by suitable cultural practices and regular monitoring.
Healthy grapes.treatment: Annual size, balanced fertilization, controlled irrigation, preventive phytosanitary surveillance.

Grape leaf burn (isariopsis sheet spot).description: Mushroom causing dark brown angular spots on the leaves, reducing the photosynthetic surface.
Grape leaf burn (isariopsis sheet spot).symptoms: Dark brown angular spots with black, often delimited by ribs, sometimes with gray sporulation on the reverse.
Grape leaf burn (isariopsis sheet spot).development: Favored by high humidity and moderate temperatures. Spreads by splashes and wind.
Grape leaf burn (isariopsis sheet spot).treatment: Elimination of affected leaves, preventive fungicidal treatments, ventilation of plant cover, weeding under the row.

Grasshoper.description: Phytophagous jumper insects that consume leaves, stems and sometimes fruits, causing massive defoliations.
Grasshoper.symptoms: Roded leaves, cut stems, slowed growth, presence of adult or nymphs.
Grasshoper.development: Multiple generations per year. Migration possible over long distances. Prumps favored by drought followed by rain.
Grasshoper.treatment: Monitoring, targeted treatment at the start of infestation, physical barriers, introduction of natural predators (birds, reptiles).

Green Mite.description: A mite sucking sap causing yellow spots, a wilting and a reduction in photosynthesis.
Green Mite.symptoms: Yellow spots on leaves, deformation, premature fall, slowed growth, 'candlestick' appearance on terminal shoots.
Green Mite.development: Quick multiplication in the dry season. Spreads by the wind, the tools or the cuttings infested.
Green Mite.treatment: Introduction of predatory mites (*typhlodromalus aripipo*), targeted spraying, cultural rotation, elimination of residues.

Gummosis.causal agent: *Leucostoma SPP.*,*Cytospora spp.*, Physiological stress or injuries
Gummosis.description: Slow of amber gum on the trunk or branches, often linked to fungal infections or abiotic stresses.
Gummosis.symptoms: Slots in bark, eighty of gum, channies, general weakening, descendant of the branches.
Gummosis.development: Favored by injuries, excessive humidity, frost, insect attacks. The fungus penetrates through the wounds.
Gummosis.treatment: Elimination of necrotic tissues, tool disinfection, drainage improvement, preventive copper treatments, avoid injury.

Beetle leaf.description: Phytophagous insects that gnaw at the leaves, causing partial holes or defoliations.
Beetle leaf.symptoms: Circular or irregular holes in the leaves, sometimes foliar skeleton, slowed growth.
Beetle leaf.development: Active in spring and summer. Adults lay on the leaves, the larvae also feed on the foliage.
Beetle leaf.treatment: Surveillance, manual collection, anti-insect nets, targeted treatments at the start of infestation.

Burn leaf.causal agent: Water stress, calcium deficiency, excess fertilizer or fungal diseases (eg *Alternaria *, *Septoria *)
Burn leaf.description: Symptom of stress or illness, characterized by drying out of the edges or the end of the leaves.
Burn leaf.symptoms: Edges of brown or necrotic leaves, rolled up or dressed leaves, slowed growth.
Burn leaf.development: Appears in the event of water imbalance, chemical burns or fungal infection. Can evolve towards the fall of the leaves.
Burn leaf.active ingredient: According to the cause: calcium, copper, mancozèbe, irrigation adjustment
Burn leaf.treatment: Correct watering, adjust fertilization, apply an identified pathogenic fungicide, remove the affected sheets.

Curl leaf.causal agent: Begomovirus (e.g. Tomato Leaf Curl Virus), transmitted by Aleurodes (*Bemisia Tabaci*)
Curl leaf.description: Viral disease causing the winding of leaves, navism and the reduction in yield.
Curl leaf.symptoms: Leaves wrapped up or bottom, thickened, chlorosis, slowed growth, deformed or absent fruits.
Curl leaf.development: Transmitted by the Aleurodes. Early infection = severe losses. The virus persists in host plants and vectors.
Curl leaf.active ingredient: No antiviral. Vector control: spinosad, pyrethrinoids, horticultural oils
Curl leaf.treatment: Use resistant varieties, eliminate infected plants, anti-insect nets, fight against the aleurodes.

Wing.causal agent: Larves of miner flies (*Liriomyza SPP.*,*Phytomyza spp.*)
Wing.description: Larves that dig galleries in the leaves, reducing photosynthesis and weakening the plant.
Wing.symptoms: Abbed streaks or clear spots in the leaves, distorted or withered leaves, presence of larvae in the mines.
Wing.development: Quick cycle. Adults lay in the leaves, the larvae dig internal galleries.
Wing.treatment: Elimination of affected leaves, introduction of parasitoids (*Diglyphus Isaaa*), targeted treatments.

Stain leaf.description: Leaf spots caused by pathogens, reducing the photosynthetic surface and promoting the fall of the leaves.
Stain leaf.symptoms: Brown, black or yellow spots, sometimes with halo, fusion of lesions, premature fall of the leaves.
Stain leaf.development: Favored by high humidity. Spreads by splashes, tools or contaminated seeds.
Stain leaf.treatment: Elimination of affected leaves, fungicide or bactericidal treatments, plant spacing, cultural rotation.

Corn ArmyWorm.description: Very mobile and voracious caterpillar, capable of quickly destroying crops by moving en masse.
Corn ArmyWorm.symptoms: Irregular holes in the leaves, galleries in the ears, dark droppings, wilting, presence of caterpillars in groups.
Corn ArmyWorm.development: Quick cycle (30–40 days). Several generations per year. Active migration of adults.
Corn ArmyWorm.treatment: Monitoring with pheromone traps, early treatment, cultural rotation, introduction of parasitoids (*trichogrammma spp.*).

Grasshoper corn.description: Phytophagous jumper insects that consume the leaves, stems and sometimes ears, causing massive defoliations.
Grasshoper corn.symptoms: Roded leaves, cut stems, slowed growth, presence of adult or nymphs.
Grasshoper corn.development: Multiple generations per year. Prumps favored by drought followed by rain. Migration possible.
Grasshoper corn.treatment: Monitoring, targeted treatment at the start of infestation, physical barriers, introduction of natural predators (birds, reptiles).

Healthy corn.description: Vigorous plant, without symptoms of diseases or stress, with good vegetative and reproductive development.
Healthy corn.symptoms: Green leaves, rapid growth, flowering and filling of normal grains, absence of stains or deformations.
Healthy corn.development: Maintaining a good health condition by suitable cultural practices and regular monitoring.
Healthy corn.treatment: Balanced fertilization, controlled irrigation, cultural rotation, preventive phytosanitary surveillance.

Mosaic.crop: Tomato, cucumber, bean, lettuce, pepper, melon
Mosaic.description: Viral disease causing color mosaics on the leaves, deformations and a reduction in yield.
Mosaic.symptoms: Light green/yellow mosaic, deformed or tense leaves, naism, striated or bumpy fruits.
Mosaic.development: Transmitted by infected aphids, suits or seeds. Early infection = severe losses.
Mosaic.active ingredient: No antiviral. Verctors control: Pyrethrinoids, Horticultural oils.
Mosaic.treatment: Eliminate infected plants, use resistant varieties, disinfect tools, control vectors.

Haunglongbing Orange (Citrus Greening).causal agent: *Candidatus liberibacter asiaicus*, bacteria transmitted by*diaphorina citri*(Asian psyllid of citrus)
Haunglongbing Orange (Citrus Greening).description: Incurable bacterial disease causing a gradual decline of citrus fruits, with distorted and bitter fruits.
Haunglongbing Orange (Citrus Greening).symptoms: Marbled, asymmetrical leaves, small fruits, mature green, bitter taste, aborted seeds, premature fall.
Haunglongbing Orange (Citrus Greening).development: Transmitted by the shrink. The tree can remain asymptomatic for a long time but infect other trees.
Haunglongbing Orange (Citrus Greening).active ingredient: No curative treatment. Vector control: imidacloprid, horticultural oils.
Haunglongbing Orange (Citrus Greening).treatment: Eliminate infected trees, monitor psyllides, use certified plants, preventive treatments.

Bacterial fishing.description: Bacterial disease causing foliar spots, chancres on branches and fruit lesions.
Bacterial fishing.symptoms: Dark brown angular spots on leaves, sometimes perforated, chancres on branches, stained or deformed fruits.
Bacterial fishing.development: Favored by humidity and injuries. Spreads by rain, tools or insects.
Bacterial fishing.treatment: Pruning of affected parts, tool disinfection, preventive copper treatments, cultural rotation.

Healthy fishing.description: Vigorous tree, without symptoms of diseases or stress, with good vegetative and reproductive development.
Healthy fishing.symptoms: Brilliant green foliage, abundant flowering, healthy fruits, absence of cannons or spots.
Healthy fishing.development: Maintaining a good health condition by suitable cultural practices and regular monitoring.
Healthy fishing.treatment: Annual size, balanced fertilization, controlled irrigation, preventive phytosanitary surveillance.

Bacterial pepper.description: Bacterial disease causing lesions on leaves and fruits, reducing quality and yield.
Bacterial pepper.symptoms: Dark, humid, then brown spots with yellow halo over leaves, liking lesions on fruits.
Bacterial pepper.development: Favored by heat and humidity. Spreads by seeds, splashes, tools.
Bacterial pepper.treatment: Healthy seeds, disinfection of tools, preventive treatments, cultural rotation.

Healthy pepper.description: Vigorous plant, without symptoms of diseases or stress, with good vegetative and reproductive development.
Healthy pepper.symptoms: Green leaves, regular growth, normal flowering and fruiting, absence of stains or deformations.
Healthy pepper.development: Maintaining a good health condition by suitable cultural practices and regular monitoring.
Healthy pepper.treatment: Balanced fertilization, controlled irrigation, gentle size, preventive phytosanitary surveillance.

Early burn potato.description: Fungal disease causing concentric spots on the leaves, stems and fruits, reducing yield.
Early burn potato.symptoms: Brown with black stains with concentric circles, yellowing, falling leaves, lesions on stems and tubers.
Early burn potato.development: Favored by humidity and moderate temperatures. Spreads by infected splashes and debris.
Early burn potato.treatment: Cultural rotation, elimination of debris, preventive fungicidal treatments, plant spacing.

Healthy potato.description: Vigorous plant, without symptoms of diseases or stress, with good vegetative development and normal tuberization.
Healthy potato.symptoms: Green leaves, regular growth, well formed tubers, absence of stains or deformations.
Healthy potato.development: Maintaining a good health condition by suitable cultural practices and regular monitoring.
Healthy potato.treatment: Cultural rotation, balanced fertilization, buttage, controlled irrigation, phytosanitary surveillance.

Late potato burn.description: Devastating disease causing dark lesions on leaves, stems and tubers, causing rapid rot.
Late potato burn.symptoms: Dark brown spots with fuzzy edges on leaves, blackened stems, rotten tubers, unpleasant odor.
Late potato burn.development: Spreads quickly in fresh and humid weather. Spores move through wind and water.
Late potato burn.treatment: Elimination of infected plants, preventive fungicidal treatments, plant spacing, long cultural rotation.

Healthy raspberry.description: Vigorous shrub, without symptoms of diseases or stress, with good vegetative and reproductive development.
Healthy raspberry.symptoms: Dark green foliage, erect stems, abundant flowering and fruiting, absence of stains or deformations.
Healthy raspberry.development: Maintaining a good health condition by suitable cultural practices and regular monitoring.
Healthy raspberry.treatment: Annual size, balanced fertilization, mulching, controlled irrigation, preventive phytosanitary surveillance.

Red Rust.description: Disease caused by a reddish algae, affecting the leaves, branches and sometimes fruits.
Red Rust.symptoms: Reddish or orange spots on the leaves, sometimes powder, blackened or deformed branches.
Red Rust.development: Develops in hot and humid conditions. The algae penetrates by stomates or injuries.
Red Rust.treatment: Pruning of affected parts, fungicidal treatments based on copper, improvement in ventilation and drainage.

Septoria Facing Leaf.description: Mushroom causing brown to black foliar spots with light center, reducing photosynthesis.
Septoria Facing Leaf.symptoms: Small round spots at grayish center, dark edge, often with black pycnids in the center. Premature fall of the leaves.
Septoria Facing Leaf.development: Favored by high humidity and moderate temperatures. Spreads by splashes, wind and tools.
Septoria Facing Leaf.treatment: Elimination of affected leaves, preventive fungicidal treatments, plant spacing, cultural rotation.

Healthy soybeans.description: Vigorous legume plant, without symptoms of diseases or stress, with good nodulation and optimal efficiency.
Healthy soybeans.symptoms: Uniform green foliage, regular flowering, well formed pods, absence of stains or wilting.
Healthy soybeans.development: Maintaining a good health condition by adapted cultural practices, balanced fertilization and a cultural rotation.
Healthy soybeans.treatment: Inoculation with rhizobium, balanced fertilization, regular weeding, phytosanitary surveillance.

Powdery Mildew squash.description: Mushroom causing white felting on the leaves, reducing photosynthesis and yield.
Powdery Mildew squash.symptoms: White powder spots on both sides of the leaves, yellowing, drying, premature fall.
Powdery Mildew squash.development: Favored in hot and dry weather with high ambient humidity. Propagates by the wind.
Powdery Mildew squash.treatment: Eliminate the affected leaves, preventive treatments, plant spacing, resistant varieties.

Healthy strawberry.description: Vigorous plant, without symptoms of diseases or stress, with good vegetative and reproductive development.
Healthy strawberry.symptoms: Green leaves, regular growth, normal flowering and fruiting, absence of stains or deformations.
Healthy strawberry.development: Maintaining a good health condition by suitable cultural practices and regular monitoring.
Healthy strawberry.treatment: Mulching, balanced fertilization, watering at the foot, cultural rotation, phytosanitary surveillance.

Scorch leaf strawberry.description: Mushroom causing irregular brown spots on the leaves, which can cause their drying out.
Scorch leaf strawberry.symptoms: Dark brown spots with black, often irregular, merging into large necrotic areas. Dried and crisp leaves.
Scorch leaf strawberry.development: Favored by high humidity and moderate temperatures. Spreads by splashes and tools.
Scorch leaf strawberry.treatment: Elimination of affected leaves, preventive fungicidal treatments, plant spacing, ground irrigation.

Streak Virus.description: Viruses transmitted by vectors insects (cicadelles, thrips), causing chlorotic streaks and navism.
Streak Virus.symptoms: Yellow streaks parallel to ribs, deformed leaves, slowed growth, wilting, poorly formed fruits.
Streak Virus.development: Transmitted by * Cicadulina Mbila * (MSV) or Thrips (TSV). Early infection = severe losses. No semen transmission.
Streak Virus.active ingredient: No antiviral. Verctors control: spinosad, pyrethrinoids, horticultural oils.
Streak Virus.treatment: Use resistant varieties, eliminate infected plants, anti-insect nets, weeding, vectors monitoring.

Early burn tomato.description: Fungal disease causing concentric spots on the leaves, stems and fruits, reducing yield.
Early burn tomato.symptoms: Brown with black stains with concentric circles, yellowing, falling leaves, lesions on stems and fruits.
Early burn tomato.development: Spreads by infected splashes and debris. Favored by humidity and moderate temperatures.
Early burn tomato.treatment: Cultural rotation, elimination of debris, preventive fungicidal treatments, plant spacing.

Healthy tomato.description: Vigorous plant, without symptoms of diseases or stress, with good vegetative and reproductive development.
Healthy tomato.symptoms: Green leaves, regular growth, normal flowering and fruiting, absence of stains or deformations.
Healthy tomato.development: Maintaining a good health condition by suitable cultural practices and regular monitoring.
Healthy tomato.treatment: Balanced fertilization, controlled irrigation, gentle size, preventive phytosanitary surveillance.

Late tomato burns.description: Devastating disease causing dark lesions on leaves, stems and fruit, causing rapid rot.
Late tomato burns.symptoms: Dark brown spots with fuzzy edges on leaves, blackened stems, brown and soft fruits, smell of rot.
Late tomato burns.development: Spreads quickly in fresh and humid weather. Spores move through wind and water.
Late tomato burns.treatment: Elimination of infected plants, preventive fungicidal treatments, plant spacing, long cultural rotation.

Mugal sheet tomato.description: Mushroom causing fungal felting on the underside of the leaves, reducing photosynthesis.
Mugal sheet tomato.symptoms: Yellow spots on the upper side, olive felt to brown on the underside, withered, fall of the leaves.
Mugal sheet tomato.development: Favored by humidity> 85% and heat. Spreads by spores in the air, tools, seeds.
Mugal sheet tomato.treatment: Ventilation, disinfection, healthy seeds, preventive fungicide treatments, avoid sprinkling by sprinkling.

Tomato Septoria Facing Leaf.description: Fungal disease causing many small spots on the leaves, causing their premature fall.
Tomato Septoria Facing Leaf.symptoms: Small round spots at grayish center, dark edge, often with black pycnids in the center. Fall of the leaves.
Tomato Septoria Facing Leaf.development: Spreads by splashes, wind, tools. Favored by high humidity and moderate temperatures.
Tomato Septoria Facing Leaf.treatment: Elimination of affected leaves, preventive fungicidal treatments, plant spacing, cultural rotation.

Spider tomato mites two-tacheted spider.description: Very polyphagous devastating mite, causing discoloring, canvases and weakening of plants.
Spider tomato mites two-tacheted spider.symptoms: White points (Stippling), yellow then brown leaves, fine paintings, falling leaves, slowed growth.
Spider tomato mites two-tacheted spider.development: Develops quickly in hot and dry weather. Several generations per year. Infestation often at the base.
Spider tomato mites two-tacheted spider.active ingredient: Abamectine, spirototetramatis, horticultural oils, insecticide soap
Spider tomato mites two-tacheted spider.treatment: Targeted spraying, introduction of predators (*phytoseiulus persimilis*), avoid water stress, regular monitoring.

Target Tache Tache.description: Fungal disease causing circular lesions with concentric rings on leaves and fruit.
Target Tache Tache.symptoms: Brown spots with light center with concentric circles (target appearance), yellowed leaves, stained or deformed fruits.
Target Tache Tache.development: Spreads by air spores. Favored by heat and humidity. Can cause significant losses.
Target Tache Tache.treatment: Cultural rotation, elimination of debris, preventive fungicidal treatments, tolerant varieties if available.

Mosaic Virus tomato tomato.description: Very stable virus transmitted mechanically, causing mosaics, deformations and loss of yield.
Mosaic Virus tomato tomato.symptoms: Light/dark green mosaic, deformed or fern -shaped leaves, slowed growth, necrotic or striated fruits.
Mosaic Virus tomato tomato.development: Seed transmission, tools, hands, tobacco. Very persistent in plant debris (several years).
Mosaic Virus tomato tomato.active ingredient: No antiviral. Disinfection: skim milk, soap, iodized solutions.
Mosaic Virus tomato tomato.treatment: Healthy seeds, tool disinfection, avoid tobacco, eliminate infected plants, resistant varieties.

Tomato tomato yellow curl leaf virus.causal agent: Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus (TYLCV), genre *Begomovirus *, family *geminiviridae *
Tomato tomato yellow curl leaf virus.description: Viruses transmitted by the Aleurodes, causing winding of leaves, naism and falling flowers.
Tomato tomato yellow curl leaf virus.symptoms: Leaves wrapped up, thickened, marginal chlorosis, slowed growth, aborted flowering.
Tomato tomato yellow curl leaf virus.development: Transmitted by *bemisia tobacaci *. Early infection = severe losses. No semen transmission.
Tomato tomato yellow curl leaf virus.active ingredient: No antiviral. Verctors control: spinosad, pyrethrinoids, horticultural oils.
Tomato tomato yellow curl leaf virus.treatment: Resistant varieties (TYLCV), anti-insect nets, elimination of infected plants, weeding, monitoring of sunselerodes.

Verticulium Wilt.crop: Tomato, potato, eggplant, pepper, strawberry, cotton, maple, olivier
Verticulium Wilt.description: Vascular fungal disease affecting many crops, causing gradual wilt and internal discoloration of tissues.
Verticulium Wilt.symptoms: Diurnal willing of the leaves (then night recovery), yellowing of the lower leaves, marginal necrosis, slowed growth, brown streaks in the vascular tissue with the cut.
Verticulium Wilt.development: The fungus penetrates through the roots and colonizes the Xylth, blocking the circulation of water. He can persist in the soil for more than 10 years in the form of microsclerotes.
Verticulium Wilt.active ingredient: No curative fungicide. Prevention: Trichoderma spp., Biofumigation, Solarization
Verticulium Wilt.treatment: Use resistant varieties (eg ‘verticillium-Tolerant’), long cultural rotation (> 4 years), solarization of the soil, improvement in drainage, tool disinfection, supply of suppressive composts.
